content.description:
A little tricky to find, but basically head to the right end of the cliff and look for an elegant left-arching crack about 50' in height.

Easy climbing for the first 20' or so to a stance, power past the crux with a solid righthand fingerlock, and continue stemming up the beautiful dihedral to easier ground.

Boulder hop down to climber's right to descend.
content.protection: TCU's and a few nuts, a single 2" piece to protect the first 15' of easy climbing.

content.description:
Face climb up lumpy rock to gain the crack parallel to

Jim Cruise

which starts about halfway up the rock.
content.location:
The crack immediately right of

Jim Cruise

.

content.description: 3 bolt arete left of More Frozen Food.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2 to 4 inch CDs for anchor.

climbs.name: Short Crack
climbs.fa: Mike Waugh, Jim Mathews, & Dan Hershman, 1/87

content.description: Start to the right of the crack and traverse along a ramp. Mantle up and jam up to the top. Short but fun.
content.location: Located on the same face as Corner N'Crack.

climbs.name: Short and Crank
climbs.fa: Mike Waugh and Jim Mathews, December 1986

content.description: A thin crack on the edge of the face gains a small ledge above which face climbing past a prominent dark-colored knob leads to the top; the name says it all.
content.protection: Gear to 2.5 inches (including belay), include sling for knob tie-off
content.location:
Crack to arete between

Jim Cruise

and

Zebra Dihedral

.

climbs.name: The Sand Truck
climbs.fa: (TR) Jonny Woodward, 1989, FL:  Don Wilson & Jack Marshall, 1990

content.description: This route ascends a face / arete to a short crack on solid rock near the right side of a NW facing block. Difficult moves will be encountered gaining the third bolt and continue to the top. An optional .75" cam will protect the final moves but placement of the cam is strenuous. An 11c rating is solid on lead! Three out of five stars.
content.protection: Three bolts and an optional .75" cam for a crack near the top. Small to medium cams are necessary for an anchor. Downclimb a 5th class chimney to the climber's left for the descent.

climbs.name: Mrs Paul's
climbs.fa: Mike Waugh, Jim Mathews & Dan Hershman, 1/87

content.description:
This climb is easiest to find with the aid of the photo in the Vogel climbing guide. However, it can be found with a text description.

Approach the north face of the Zebra Cliffs from the end of Jumbo Rocks camping area. This is the nearest end and you will turn right (west) well below the face. Watch for a set of two square buttresses that stand out from the generally rounded features.

There is a left-facing dihedral formed between the upper left and lower right formations, this is Frozen Fish Fingers.

Scramble up to the base on lead and place a piece or two in the corner (Frozen Fish Fingers) and then step left to climb some edges and proceed upwards to the bottom of a crack (thin fingers) which widens to hands before topping out.

Although this is described as a handcrack, it is mostly fingers and small protection, to match. The belay up top requires some larger gear though.

To descend, walk back and west into a gully with some scrambling/chimney moves required.
content.protection: Finger to hand sized nuts and cams.If you do not toss a piece into Frozen Fish Fingers before starting, you will be dangerously runout at the crux.

climbs.name: More Frozen Food
climbs.fa: Mike Waugh, Jim Mathews, & Dan Hershman, 1/87

content.description: This is yet another great climb established by M. Waugh et al. on the Zebra Cliffs. The route begins left of the Sand Truck and ascends the obvious crack in the middle of the block. Near the top the crack ends and a short traverse left is necessary to gain another thin crack. Placing pro is somewhat challenging in the upper crack where the crux is located.
content.protection: Small stoppers and cams to .5" for pro with a few long runners. Some of the placements are challenging but solid. Cams are necessary for an anchor.

climbs.name: Jim Cruise
climbs.fa: Jim Mathews, Mike Waugh and Will Chen, December 1986

content.description: Around the corner to the left of The Zebra Dihedral ~70 ft. Climb thin parallel seams. Steep at the bottom, eases towards the top.

climbs.name: Holden Down the Fort
climbs.fa: Mark Holden, Joe Grant and Rick Camp, April 1993

content.description: Start up a thin curving rail and continue up the sculpted face to a narrow ledge, finishing with a short headwall.
content.location:
The face just left of

Zebra Dihedral

.

climbs.name: Fruit Stripe
climbs.fa: Karen Roseme and Chris Miller, October 1998

content.description: Climbs a short section of face to the left side of a narrow ledge and then continues up the thin technical face above past multiple stripes of patina. Short but quality.
content.location:
The smooth face between

Jim Cruise

and

Short and Crank

.

climbs.name: Frozen Fish Fingers
climbs.fa: Mike Waugh, Jim Mathews & Dan Hershman, 1/87

content.description:
This climb is easiest to find with the aid of the photo in the Vogel climbing guide. However, it can be found with a text description.

Approach the north face of the Zebra Cliffs from the end of Jumbo Rocks camping area. This is the nearest end and you will turn right (west) well below the face. Watch for a set of two square buttresses that stand out from the generally rounded features.

There is a left-facing dihedral formed between the upper left and lower right formations, this is Frozen Fish Fingers.

Scramble up to the base on lead and place a piece in the corner and proceed upwards to the top of the rock. Although this is described as a handcrack, it is mostly fingers and small protection, to match. The belay up top requires some larger gear though. To descend, walk back and west into a gully with some scrambling/chimney moves required.
content.protection: Ffinger to hand sized nuts and cams.

content.description:
Uninspiring crack with plenty of face holds.

Definitely cruise control, but would be a great first lead for a new Trad Climber, with plenty of obvious pro, and zero stress climbing.
content.location: Left of the large block with Mrs Paul's and Frozen Fish Fingers routes.

climbs.name: Corner N' Crack
climbs.fa: Mike Waugh, Jim Mathews & Dan Hershman, 1/87

content.description: This route is quite short.  However, it has great rock and really fun moves.
content.location: Start high on the north face.  Traverse right around a corner onto the northwest face, and then go up when the crack bends left.

climbs.name: Aging Hippie Crack
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett and Karen Tracy, March 1990

content.description: This is a vertical straight-in thin crack on a pocketed wall. It is surprisingly strenuous.  This route does not get sun until mid-late afternoon.
content.location: This climb goes up a separate formation near the right side of the northwest part of Zebra Cliffs.  There is a crack on the formation that doesn't reach the top or the bottom.
